petitioner.name: JEFFREY A. BEARD, SECRETARY, PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Beard v. Banks. Mr. Rovelli.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Rovelli, I -- I forget. How big a class of -- of prisoners are we talking about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Less than 40? And does the record tell us how long they have been in level 2?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But is there any average or any -- is there -- does the record tell us how -- how long most of them have been there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Does that mean that 75 percent had not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And how long -- do we know what the average period of incarceration in level 2 is? Is it a matter of weeks, or is it a matter of years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm trying to understand whether typically they're there for a long period of time on the one hand, or are they there sort of on probation and are periodically reviewed and moved into another system?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Were there any prisoners, since the inception to your program, that have been in there for the whole 2 years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are -- do -- is -- is Pennsylvania alone or nearly alone in imposing this rule, or is this typical of the restraints imposed in -- in this maximum restrictive confinement? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is this one of the most severe restrictions in the Nation with respect to reading material and photographs?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is the reason that -- that the State or the regulations allow paperbacks from the library and not current events? I'm just -- that -- the rationality of -- of that line escapes me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can we explain that? How 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- does one use a newspaper as a weapon? I mean, you know, maybe disciplining a dog or something. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But a paperback version of War and Peace is less dangerous? It seems a

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But if the concern is the safety concern, then you would have an equal concern with the Jewish Daily Forward, which is a newspaper format, or -- and I don't know what the Watchtower comes out in these days.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's why I thought your answer would have focused on that rather than the security concerns, is that you take away what it is they want the most because that's most likely to result in them conforming their behavior so they can get it back.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So why -- let's see. They go to the prison library what? Once every couple of weeks or what? Once a week?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: One -- one visit per month. And -- and how often do they go to the prison library?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's ordered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, what it says -- that's what -- it says, to review legal materials, one at a time may be let out of his cell and is escorted to a mini law library in hand. All right. Why couldn't you have a -- if he wants to see the newspaper in that mini law library, why couldn't there be a copy there, only the parts that are consistent with the censorship policy, just like a news of the day.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there a security reason or is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there a security reason when he's there in leg irons looking at the books, the law books, in the mini law library?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What does the -- what does the inmate have to show in order to go to the law library? That is, suppose the inmate's position is I want to go there and I want to read Law Week and Legal Times and other -- I want to see what's new, what's breaking in the law so that maybe I'll have something I can put in a petition, and that's why I want to go every -- every chance I get to the law library. Could such an inmate go to the library?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, that would mean that the inmate could go and look at the legal newspapers, but not -- not the Christian Science Monitor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So he could get Law Week, Legal Times, and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the National Law Journal. All of those he could get.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Now, on -- on your theory of -- of behavior modification, would it, nonetheless, be -- be open to the State to say, no, you may not receive any more legal materials and you may not go to the library to look at them? Because that's something you very much want to do. And in order to do that, you've got to shape up and -- and get moved down to a lesser level of security. Would that -- I'm not saying that the State is -- is about to do that, but on your theory, could the State do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, what would -- I mean, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 you know, one of the arguments made on the other side is that if you accept the behavior modification theory as an adequate justification, the Turner categories essentially become incoherent. What, for example, would be the alternative means in this case if the State said, we realize that the people in -- in -- at level 2 want to see legal materials very, very much because that is a source of hope for them, and we want them to have that source of hope only if they shape up and -- and get down to a reduced level of security, so we're going to stop it, period? What would be the alternatives within the -- the Turner analysis?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What if the -- what if the inmate said, look, the -- the lawyers who come to see us are -- are great guys, but they're -- they're overworked. They don't have time to be thinking about novel legal theories, which we would dream up perhaps if we could get to Legal Times and these periodicals? So it's -- it's not an alternative. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you're -- you're saying there -- there's a separate value here, and that is the value of access to courts. And -- and that limits what can be done for purposes of behavior modification.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right. What about the marriage example? The -- the Court has said, yes, you couldn't -- the -- the State can't prevent the inmate from -- from getting married. I don't see where the separate source of -- of value is that would -- that -- that would affect that analysis. No right of access to court. The associational rights can be abridged and so on. Why, on your analysis, wouldn't -- wouldn't the proper disposition of the earlier case have been to say, yes, the State can preclude marriage too because that's something they very much want and -- and the State can preclude that unless they shape up and -- and get down to a -- a lesser level of security?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you're saying there just is not a logical connection there within --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the meaning of the -- of the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But there would be a logical connection for those who want to get married.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You're -- you're saying it might not make sense as a systemic policy --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- because it isn't a big enough problem. But for -- we're not talking about a whole system here. We're talking about 40 people or less, and if some of those 40 people want to get married, why doesn't it make perfect sense to say no 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 marriage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You can, and on -- on your analysis, why isn't that sufficient?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay, but how do we get around the marriage case then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So as to these, the -- the marriage could be banned, in effect, you're saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I thought there, there was a genuine security concern, which I think you pretty much said doesn't exist here when you consider what they can have in -- in the cell.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Rovelli. Mr. Marcus.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Where do you draw the line? I take it somewhere -- you couldn't deprive them of food, if that would get them to -- to conform. Justice Souter was asking about marriage. I mean, how do we tell when -- when you can deprive someone of something they -- to modify their behavior and when it goes too far?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But don't we -- don't we have the same problem if we're -- if we're dealing with First Amendment interests that we do when we're dealing with Eighth Amendment interests? In other words, if -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 if we don't say, well, they get outside of Turner analysis because they require -- by virtue of being enumerated rights, they require an analysis specific to them, is the abridgement of the right carried so far that it is unreasonable? If we don't say that, then I don't see, as your friends on the other side have argued, I don't see where the logical stopping point is if we accept the -- the behavior modification theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Oh, oh, I -- I realize that. I mean, they're -- they're making an in extremis kind of argument. I understand that. But if -- if we accept an in extremis kind of argument on the theory of behavior modification, then I don't see why that argument does not, for example, cover the marriage case, and maybe -- maybe it should. I don't know why that argument would not allow for a total deprivation of all communication outside of, let's say, access to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 counsel. And -- and so it seems to me that whether we admit it or not, what's going on here, whether we call it Turner analysis or not, is we're making some kind of a judgment as to whether they're carrying the deprivation for behavior modification purposes in these extreme cases too far.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And if that's what -- I'll -- I'll be quiet in a second. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If that's -- if that's what we're doing, aren't we just as much outside the Turner analysis when we're talking about the First Amendment or associational rights under the First Amendment as we are when we're talking about the Eighth Amendment? And shouldn't we say so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So -- so but at some point, there's sort of a reasonableness limit then you're saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do -- do you concede that just because a right is enumerated, it means it cannot be entirely taken away in prison?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, like, you know, try the right to bear arms. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Apart from those two, access to the courts and cruel and unusual punishment, then anything goes for this set of incorrigible prisoners? They can take away -- the First Amendment, in other words, is out the window. They have no First Amendment rights that the State needs to respect. Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But -- but for this -- for this group, while they're in that situation, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 essentially there's no First Amendment rights. I think that's what your -- your argument. They can regain them, but that's the purpose of the behavioral modification program. But the -- the only thing that these prisoners get is the Eighth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Marcus, I was kind of interested in your calling this an incentive program. Is there any -- there are no intermediate stages. It's an all-or-nothing incentive, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, I mean, with respect to the prisoners in this population. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, I didn't understand that the -- the prisoners in this particular part of the prison had any intermediate incentive. They either get out after a year or 2 or they don't. Isn't that right? I mean, they either get to a different classification.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: There's no scoring. You've got 25 points now, so you're pretty close to your goal or anything like -- it's not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- not like most incentive programs I've heard about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And -- and does the review correlate it in any way with these particular deprivations? I mean, what is the review -- how does the review correlate with their inability to get reading materials?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is there any evidence at all that the amount of reading that they do has any correlation to their opportunity for getting better assignments?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes. That there's any correlation whatsoever between how much these people -- these prisoners read and when they get into the next level of the prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So the legal issues would be precisely the same if the State denied totally any reading material to the prisoners. We'd have the same issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Why would it be more difficult?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I understood your argument to, in effect, contend that the behavior modification rationale will justify the program no matter what the balancing process is.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Marcus.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Krakoff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well -- well, it seems to me that that's an as-applied challenge. If -- if a particular inmate -- the terms of -- the conditions of confinement are particularly harsh and he -- he or she has an unrealistic opportunity to get to a less 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 restrictive confinement, then -- then he can bring a suit.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Krakoff, what -- I take it you wouldn't have any objection to terminating of television rights, for example. If prisoners have the right to watch television, they misbehave, the penalty is no television. Is that all right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What other alternatives would you have the prison administrators rely on? You have an incorrigible prisoner who's misbehaving. He won't behave. They go through every -- he gets up to level -- level 2. What -- what should they have done instead?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. What should they have done instead? Let's say he gets out of the prison 1 hour every other day. Should they have taken that hour out? I mean, not out of the prison. Out of his cell. Should they have taken that hour away, or what -- what other options do they have?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right, and I want you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 to tell me --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I would like you to tell me what else they should have done. Why is that wrong?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And none of that worked. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So your answer to my question is there's nothing else they could have done, but they shouldn't have done this because this wasn't going to work either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but consistent --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Consistently with your answer, it seems to me, you have to say they should give the TV back, they should give the magazines back because none of those worked either. And those are First Amendment deprivations to some degree.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. But I mean, what's -- what's your answer to my question? It seems to me that your point to the Chief Justice was the courts have to review the efficacy of these moves.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And if -- if there is no efficacy and there is an infringement of what, at least for people on the outside, would be a protected right, then they have no justification for taking those rights away. And if that's going to be the analysis, then on -- on the argument you just gave, they've got to give the TV rights back, they've got to give the magazine rights back, and so on. Isn't that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I sure would like that, but (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But then why? Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right. And in -- in your argument, in your answer to the Chief Justice, you were pointing out a situation in which taking away the TV didn't work, taking away the magazines didn't work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why then do they not, on your theory, have to give TV and magazines back?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right. Then where does your efficacy criterion go? You're saying they may make judgments, and apparently they may -- may make judgments and maintain them even if those judgments do not, in fact, advance their interests. Here, you're saying they -- it's not going to advance their interests, so they can't do it. In these cases, you're saying they don't advance their interests, but they can as a matter of judgment. And I don't know how to draw that line.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but -- the whole rationale of your case -- if I were you writing your brief, I would have this problem. This really matters to the inmates, but that's exactly the State's point. That's the reason it's taken away. It really means something. And I -- I just -- I just don't know what to do with that conundrum.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and it seems to me it's the heart of your case and that it surfaces here in the answers you've attempted to give.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But the whole basis 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 for the suit is that it matters to the prisoner, and that's exactly why it's been taken away because there's nothing else left that we can do with these prisoners.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about changing other people's behavior? Your -- your assertion that it does no good is based upon the fact that it has not altered the behavior of these people who are in the unit. But what about other people who don't want to get thrown in the unit? I mean, don't you have to look at the deterrent effect? And -- and is it easy for you to say that the -- that -- that the in terrorem effect of being deprived of -- of literature, television, or whatever has not induced other people to shape up?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I think it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So let's say if -- if the flaw is it doesn't deter other people because they don't know about it, then if they -- if they broadcast it all over so everyone knows about it, then it's okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But is there other -- are there other bases? Because so far your argument is they're so bad that you might as well give them whatever they want because it won't matter. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, I'm parodying it, but you understand why I don't think it's your strongest for the reasons said. But are there others which might be a little -- you had other arguments --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. It has nothing to do with the law. I understand your argument. Your argument that you have made is, at the very least, you can't say that this deterrent effect is that big a deal. I mean, now, there were other reasons justifying it. They said, for example, if one --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, and they made a big case in this. It's on 188 in the appendix.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And they made a major point. They said that with the newspapers, they set fires, they throw feces. They use them as a spear, and then when asked, why couldn't you do the same with library books, or couldn't you do the same with paperbacks, they said, yes, it's possible, but it's less likely 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 because of the size of the document. And we don't have to forbid everything. We just forbid the things that we think are particularly likely. Now, what about that one?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, then now you're giving -- now you're making their situation worse because they tried to make your client's situation better. I mean, yes, they could -- maybe they could prohibit religious journals as well, but they -- for various reasons, they decided not to do that. Maybe they could have eliminated legal materials as well, but again, they decided not to do it. They take a more circumscribed approach. So I'm not sure it's a very effective response to say, well, they let religious materials in and that can be used as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought you were using that to say that the security concern doesn't hold up 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 because of the papers that they're allowed to have in their cells can be used similarly for fires, similarly to do other bad things.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So I thought that's why you were using that, just to say that the -- the security concern is dubious because the materials that they are allowed to have in their cells can -- could achieve exactly the same end.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you know what kind of a fire you can make with the Sunday New York Times? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are you going to -- are you going to compare that to writing paper and -- and to -- to the Jewish Advocate or whatever it is? I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it seems to me a perfectly reasonable line. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if visitors -- if there's a security issue with visitors to the prisoner, you're saying you can't prohibit visitors because if you allow the lawyers to come in, because they're visitors too?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it wouldn't undermine the security rationale just because you have some exceptions where there are other countervailing interests that might outweigh the security concern.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is it that I should read then in respect to what's actually bothering me? In Turner v. Safley --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the Court says we resolve, when a prison regulation impinges on an inmate's constitutional rights, which it does here, the regulation is valid if it is reasonably related to legitimate penological interests. That standard is necessary if prison administrators and not the courts are to make the difficult judgments concerning institutional operations. And that's where I think it's difficult to balance this case. If we were to decide for you, are we going too far in interfering on what the prison administrators should be doing, or have they gone too far? Now, if I'm supposed to look at this record and try and make up my mind, which I think is about that question, what do you want me to look at? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I'll read the briefs. I have no problem with the briefs --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you this 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You said that the prison grapevine really doesn't tell the prisoners about this particular lack of access to public materials. Does the prison grapevine let them know that they're going to be in the cell for 23 hours a day and only be out 1 hour a day?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If that is generally known, it would seem to me that that itself would be sufficient incentive to try and avoid this program, whether or not you're going to be able to read the Christian Science Monitor or the New York Times. It seems to me that the -- the -- what we're fighting about is trivial compared to the very obvious deterrent value of 23 hours in the same cell 7 days a week, 30 days a month, 365 days a year. I don't think I'd care about this other stuff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, I could say the same thing about going to jail, I mean, at all. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You know, I could say whether I'm there 23 hours or all or not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it's enough of an incentive that I -- that I don't want to go to jail. There's -- there's incentives and there's incentives.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And once you're in that situation already, as these prisoners are, and they're still not conforming their behavior to the prison rules, you have a limited number of options for trying to get them to do that, and your response to my first line of questioning was that there's nothing else you can think of that they could do.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So your response is they should just grin and bear it. They --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I -- may I interrupt you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- with this question? Aren't you really saying that when the deprivations get beyond some point, some serious point, the issue is not properly analyzed under Turner and Safley, can they do one thing more? The issue really becomes one of cruel and unusual punishment. Is the totality that they have taken away so great that it is cruel to maintain these people under these circumstances? Is that the argument you're really making?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Oh, I know that wasn't -- that wasn't the claim that you made, but isn't that the argument that you're making?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but the State's position is that it wants to avoid that ultimate deterrent. It -- it wants to take away privileges for a while to see if he can conform. You're depriving the State of the -- of the option to avoid the most extreme circumstances of forgetting about him altogether forever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And it seems to me that -- that your -- your argument is -- is at cross ends with its own purpose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Just let me just ask one -- one thing I am curious about. The argument -- it seems to me that there's kind of a flow of these. Some of them get out of this system and some stay a long time. What does the record tell us about how often, if they conform to the regular rules without any violation for 40 days or a year, do they -- do they get out of this -- this situation? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm not posing what the rules say. Does the record tell us whether -- you know, whether this system is just something we're talking about or whether it really has an effect on people moving from this classification to another classification.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What -- this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What other than the periodical, newspaper access differentiates this custody from the next higher --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Rovelli, you have 2 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Rovelli, do the other prisoners know about this? I'd like you to respond to the -- to the assertion that nobody knows about this anyway, so it doesn't deter anybody.
